list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Jessica hits a tennis serve and the path of the ball can be modelled by
the function
$$$h(d)=2+d−5d2​​$$$
where $h$ is the height
above ground level in meters, and $d$ is the horizontal distance the
tennis ball travels, also in meters.


Find the horizontal distance travelled by the ball when it hits the
ground.[2]



Find the maximum height the ball reaches.[2]



On her next serve, Jessica hits the ball harder and flatter, so that the
ball reaches the same height as the previous serve, but travels twice as
far.

Determine a new height function, $h2​$, that describes this
trajectory.[2]
list.markScheme:
If we sketch the graph of $h(d)$, for $d≥0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5e48f29e-d2ab-494f-8541-86971485cc14/images/1dffd0c1-fe52-4cec-96e8-2a22889cea3f/2b33f5ae4640acb6d33c7265f26c197540d4968e.svg)


Hence the horizontal distance travelled by the ball is:
$6.53m.​$


From part (a) we see the maximum height is:
$3.25m.​$


The trajectory $h2​$ is an horizontal stretch of $h(d)$ by a scale
factor of $2$.
Therefore, we get
$$$h2​(d)​=2+2d​−5(d/2)2​h2​(d)=2+2d​−20d2​​​$$$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
A government has a piecewise function, $T$, to calculate the amount of
taxes a citizen has to pay quarterly, according to their quarterly
income, $x$, given by
$$$T(x)=⎩⎨⎧​050000(x−5000)2​51​x−1000​x≤50005000<x≤1500015000<x​$$$


Find the quarterly taxes a citizen has to pay for incomes
of


$9 000


$16 000[2]





The government is considering increasing the tax rates and is
contemplating the following two options:
$$
Option 1: Increase taxes by $100 on all levels, and then by a factor of 1.15
$Option 2: Increase taxes using the model T(1.4x+1000)$

Determine functions to model the taxes for each of these
options.[4]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating each income value in the corresponding component of the
function, we get


$T(9000)​=50000(9000−5000)2​[as 5000<9000<15000]=320​​$


$T(16000)​=51​(16000)−1000[as 15000<16000]=2200​​$




Let's denote $T1​(x)$ the tax function for option 1 and $T2​(x)$ the
function for option 2.
Using the appropriate stretches and translations to the tax function
$T(x)$, we get
$$$T1​(x)=⎩⎨⎧​1151.15[50000(x−5000)2​+100]1.15[51​x−900]​x≤50005000<x≤1500015000<x​​$$$
and
$$$T2​(x)=⎩⎨⎧​050000(1.4x−4000)2​51.4x−4000​​x≤50005000<x≤1500015000<x​​$$$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
A soccer ball is kicked from the ground such that its path can be
modelled by the function
$$$h(d)=d−6d2​​$$$
where $h$ is the height above
ground level in meters, and $d$ is the horizontal distance the ball
travels, also in meters.


Find the distance travelled by the ball when it hits the
ground.[2]



Find the maximum height the ball reaches.[2]



The soccer player now practices kicking the ball shorter, so that it
travels half the vertical height and half the horizontal distance as the
previous kick.

Determine the height function, $h2​$, that describes this
new trajectory.[2]
list.markScheme:
If we sketch the graph of $h(d)$, for $d≥0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/83d15e38-1571-4e43-bef1-f0d2b5e95cd9/images/2b6df9f1-7438-4068-a001-809bea436160/dc03a8c401d7ff9b93bbae51a1b1a543d21e61fa.svg)


Hence the distance travelled by the ball is:
$6m.​$


From part (a) we see the maximum height is:
$1.5m.​$


The trajectory $h2​$ is an horizontal stretch of $h(d)$ by a scale
factor of $2$ and a vertical stretch of $h(d)$ by a scale factor of
$21​$.
Hence, we get
$$$h2​(d)​=21​((2d)−6(2d)2​)h2​(d)=d−3d2​​​$$$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Let $f(x)=sinx$,  for $x∈R$. The
graph of $f$ is translated by
$(p−q​)$
to give the graph of a function $g$ that passes through the points
A$(0,−7)$ and B$(π,−5)$. It is given that $0<p≤2π$.
Find the value of $p$ and the value of $q$.
list.markScheme:
Since the graph of $f$ has been translated $p$ units in the direction of
the positive $x$-axis and $q$ units in the direction of the negative
$y$-axis, an expression for $g$ is given by
$$$g(x)​=f(x−p)−q=sin(x−p)−q​$$$
Hence, using the
coordinates of A$(0,−7)$ and B$(π,−5)$, we get
$$$−7−5​=sin(−p)−q=sin(π−p)−q​$$$
Therefore we have two expressions for $q$:
$$$qq​=sin(−p)+7[1]=sin(π−p)+5[2]​$$$
Hence, we solve the following equation for $p$:
$$$sin(−p)+7​=sin(π−p)+5​$$$
By using the G.D.C. we find $p≈1.57 or 2π​​$
And substituting this value into equation [1], $q=6​$.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Let $f(x)=ex$,  for $x∈R$. The
graph of $f$ is translated by
$(−pq​)$
to give the graph of a function $g$ that passes through the points
A$(0,1.5)$ and B$(ln2,2)$.
Find the value of $p$ and the value of $q$.
list.markScheme:
Since the graph of $f$ has been translated $p$ units in the direction of
the negative $x$-axis and $q$ units in the direction of the positive
$y$-axis, an expression for $g$ is given by
$$$g(x)g(x)​=f(x+p)+q=ex+p+q[for x∈R]​$$$
Hence, using the coordinates of A$(0,1.5)$ and B$(ln2,2)$, we get
$$$1.52​=ep+q=eln2+p+q​$$$
Therefore we have two expressions for $q$:
$$$qq​=1.5−ep[1]=2−eln2+p[2]​$$$
Hence, we solve the following equation for $p$:
$$$1.5−ep​=2−eln2+p​$$$
By using the G.D.C. we find $p≈−0.693​$
And substituting this value into equation [1], $q=1​$.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
A scientist is studying the growth of a population of bacteria under
different environments. In environment $A$ bacteria grows according to
the function
$$$G(t)=−700(0.95)t+750$$$
where $G$ is the population of
bacteria and $t$ is the time in minutes since placed in the environment.


Find the initial population of bacteria.[1]



Sketch a graph of $G$ against $t$ for $0≤t≤800$.[3]



Find the population of bacteria after 20 minutes.[1]



Find the steady-state population of bacteria after a long period of
time.[1]



To slow down the growth of bacteria, the scientist creates a new
environment, $B$, by reducing the pH level of the environment. The
scientist finds that the bacteria now grow half as fast as in
environment $A$.

Determine a model for the growth of bacteria $G2​$ for this
modified environment.[2]


The scientist creates a another environment, $C$, which is rich in
proteins. The scientist finds that the bacteria grows twice as fast as
in the original environment, $A$.


Determine a model for the growth, $G3​$, of bacteria in
this protein-rich environment.[2]



Find out how long it takes for the population of bacteria
to reach $600$ in environment $C$.[2]
list.markScheme:
The initial population of bacteria is given by $G(0)$.
Therefore, the initial population is
$50bacteria​$


The graph of $G$ versus $t$ for $0≤t≤800$ is shown below
[by using G.D.C.]


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe00e51d-9360-4650-9d14-97738ef54068/images/2f3e2cd8-4af8-4ed7-a759-27ddc45c6063/6c875d0f390136f8009b8bc56f5fb4337484b581.svg)




The population after $20$ minutes is given by $G(20)$. We get
$$$G(20)​=−700(0.95)20+750≈499 bacteria​[by using G.D.C.]​$$$


From the graph in part (a) we can see that the steady-state
population of bacteria after a long period of time is
$$$750bacteria​$$$


The new function $G2​(t)$ is found by transforming the graph of
$G(t)$ by a stretch with scale factor $2$ and $y$-axis invariant.
Therefore, we get
$$$G2​(t)=−700(0.95)t/2+750​$$$


The function $G3​(t)$ can be found by transforming the graph of
$G(t)$ by a stretch with scale factor $21​$ and $y$-axis
invariant. Therefore, we get
$$$G3​(t)=−700(0.95)2t+750​$$$


If we draw the graph of $G3​$ versus $t$ and $y=600$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe00e51d-9360-4650-9d14-97738ef54068/images/d92a8d2a-3424-4da1-a720-36f21c7070a6/99ecd8a838edd38c55b6acb6559f25b64ad90f4d.svg)


Therefore, the population of bacteria in environment $C$ reaches 600
after
$$$15 minutes​$$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
A company that produces electronic components is investigating the
heating properties of a particular component. The company finds that the
temperature, $T$, of the component can be modelled by the function
$$$T(t)=−40(0.9)t+90$$$
where $T$ is measured in degrees Celsius and $t$
is measured in minutes of use.


Write down the initial temperature of the component.[1]



Sketch a graph of $T$ against $t$ for $0≤t≤90$.[3]



Find the temperature of the component after 15 minutes.[1]



Find the steady-state temperature of the component after a long
duration of use.[1]



To slow down the heating speed of the component, the company increases
the size of the component in such a way that the component heats
$43​$ times as fast as the initial component.

Find a model for the temperature $T2​$ of the modified
component.[2]


Another option to reduce the rate of heating - instead of increasing the
size of the component - is to add a thermal pad to the component. In
this case the component heats half as fast as the initial component.


Find a model for the temperature $T3​$ of the component
with the thermal pad.[2]



Find the time taken for the component with the thermal pad
to reach $80∘$ C.[2]
list.markScheme:
The initial temperature of the component is given by $T(0)$.
Hence, the initial temperature is
$50∘C​$


The graph of $T$ versus $t$ [by using G.D.C.] for
$0≤t≤90$ is shown below


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/312f2f89-1d5d-405d-a0c2-4d85e141d1f1/images/6b0861aa-46fb-422c-bd98-e606811b0839/1ea4bfa73ce4f9b86bdbec79080f39dd70e04a16.svg)




The temperature after $15$ minutes is given by $T(15)$. We get
$$$T(15)​=−40(0.9)15+90≈81.8∘C​[by using G.D.C.]​$$$


From the graph in part (a) we can see that the steady-state
temperature after a long duration of use is:
$$$90∘C​$$$


The new function $T2​(t)$ is found by transforming the graph of
$T(t)$ by a stretch with scale factor $34​$ and $y$-axis
invariant. Therefore, we get
$$$T2​(t)=−40(0.9)3t/4+90​$$$


The function $T3​(t)$ can be found by transforming the graph of
$T(t)$ by a stretch with scale factor $2$ and $y$-axis invariant.
Therefore, we get
$$$T3​(t)=−40(0.9)t/2+90​$$$


The graph of $T3​$ versus $t$ and $y=80$ if shown [by using
G.D.C.]


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/312f2f89-1d5d-405d-a0c2-4d85e141d1f1/images/c7b35707-711b-41cf-a85e-50baa7b62145/787dac570c08164c400ae6f2d2de11249fcfecc8.svg)


Therefore, the component reaches a temperature of
$80∘$ C after
$$$26.3 minutes​$$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Evan has inserted a photo of a bridge into graphing software. The photo shows a suspension cable hanging between two vertical suspenders. The part of the cable between the vertical suspenders in the photo has equation
$$$h(x)=537​x2+2,−4.6≤x≤4.6​$$$
Where $h$ and $x$ are measured in centimetres. The bridge deck lies on the $x$-axis.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3f772715-8d4c-4baa-9dbe-4e511990717a/images/75ae16ef-0328-41f3-9043-658d6250a532/ai1061.PNG)


The photo is an enlargement of the actual bridge with a scale factor of $1251​$ and centre $(0,0)$.


Find the equation of the actual suspension cable between the vertical suspenders. Give your answer in the form $f(x)=ax2+b$, where $a,b∈R$.[3]



Hence, calculate the area bound by the vertical suspenders, the bridge deck and the suspension cable. Give your answer in m$2$.[2]
list.markScheme:
Let the equation of the actual suspension cable be $f(x)$. Therefore, using both a vertical enlargement and horizontal enlargement of scale factor $1251​$ we have
$$$h(x)=1251​f(125x)​$$$
Expressing $f(x)$ in terms of $h(x)$ we have
$$$f(x)​=125h(125x​)=125(537​(125x​)2+2)f(x)=0.001057x2+250,−575≤x≤575​​$$$


The area required is given by the integral
$$$A​=∫−575575​0.001057x2+250dx≈421000cm2​$$$
We can convert area in $cm2$ to area in $m2$ by dividing by $1002$.
The area bound by the vertical suspenders, the bridge deck and the suspension cable is approximately $42.1m2$.
